pullRequest.body:
Several definitions in homological algebra or category theory are *very* slow to compile. This PR makes them (and any downstream definitions depending on them) noncomputable. This is somewhat invasive, but also yields measurable speed-ups: affected files sometimes get 50% faster; on all of mathlib, this saves 10% of all compilation time, and about 620*10⁹ instructions (0.5% of all of mathlib).

----------
Still fails the style linter, so a proof-of-concept: I'd be interested in hearing whether this PR is considered worth it.

This PR also used to contain other changes, which have landed as dependent PRs.

This fixes all files whose compilation took longer than 10 seconds -- except for unavoidable ones like tactic files and `Data.MLList.BestFirst`, `AlgebraicTopology.DoldKan.EquivalencePseudoabelian` (separate PR) and `Sites.Sheaf` (no speed-up when benchmarking).

---

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/a63c3510-6f58-4cb0-880a-7a2d58b92619/to/1269a809-e012-4a18-8776-6f4e95ca4a68) against commit 2764b3b7b6465e84a413a4a741e7820bbef0d7c5:
```diff
  Benchmark                                             Metric         Change
  ===========================================================================
+ build                                                 aesop           -7.5%
+ build                                                 compilation     -9.4%
+ ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.OfNorm            instructions   -26.7%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Presheaf                instructions   -31.7%

+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.ComposableArrows              instructions   -17.6%

+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.ConeCategory           instructions   -35.0%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.TensorAlgebra.Grading          instructions   -77.9%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Decomposition.RadonNikodym     instructions   -45.6%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Decomposition.SignedLebesgue   instructions   -60.1%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Group.Convolution              instructions   -85.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.Padics.PadicNumbers             instructions   -58.4%
+ ~Mathlib.Probability.Independence.Basic               instructions   -32.5%
+ ~Mathlib.Probability.Independence.Conditional         instructions   -33.8%
+ ~Mathlib.Probability.Independence.Kernel              instructions   -21.0%
```

Benchmarking results are in. Disentangling the various PRs, I get the following effects
- the `ofNorm` change wins 23 billion instructions (but is a clear win)
- the `Padics` change wins about 70 billion instructions
- using `suppress_compilation` in `TensorAlgebra/Grading` wins 70 billion
- expanding slow `measurability` calls nets 160 billion
altogether about 330 billion instructions.
The remaining 795-330=465 billion instructions are because of this PR.

pullRequest.title: chore: make expensive definitions noncomputable

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ff99fb00d9](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13774/commits/ff99fb00d946ae38a09b5e71a5d5c353295121b9)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |

nodes.body: !bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/1269a809-e012-4a18-8776-6f4e95ca4a68) for commit 1edd7d274f683b2e10086e9120d0e00559e39133.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/a63c3510-6f58-4cb0-880a-7a2d58b92619/to/1269a809-e012-4a18-8776-6f4e95ca4a68) against commit 2764b3b7b6465e84a413a4a741e7820bbef0d7c5:
```diff
  Benchmark                                             Metric         Change
  ===========================================================================
+ build                                                 aesop           -7.5%
+ build                                                 compilation     -9.4%
+ ~Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.OfNorm            instructions   -26.7%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Presheaf                instructions   -31.7%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.StructuredArrow         instructions   -60.7%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.ComposableArrows              instructions   -17.6%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Elements                      instructions   -35.6%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Functor.KanExtension.Basic    instructions   -71.8%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.GuitartExact.Basic            instructions   -20.9%
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Limits.ConeCategory           instructions   -35.0%
+ ~Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.TensorAlgebra.Grading          instructions   -77.9%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Decomposition.RadonNikodym     instructions   -45.6%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Decomposition.SignedLebesgue   instructions   -60.1%
+ ~Mathlib.MeasureTheory.Group.Convolution              instructions   -85.6%
+ ~Mathlib.NumberTheory.Padics.PadicNumbers             instructions   -58.4%
+ ~Mathlib.Probability.Independence.Basic               instructions   -32.5%
+ ~Mathlib.Probability.Independence.Conditional         instructions   -33.8%
+ ~Mathlib.Probability.Independence.Kernel              instructions   -21.0%
```

Benchmarking results are in. Disentangling the various PRs, I get the following effects
- the `ofNorm` change wins 23 billion instructions (but is a clear win)
- the `Padics` change wins about 70 billion instructions
- using `suppress_compilation` in `TensorAlgebra/Grading` wins 70 billion
- expanding slow `measurability` calls nets 160 billion
altogether about 330 billion instructions.
The remaining 795-330=465 billion instructions are because of this PR.
